repnme.cdata!: India - Oil and Gas Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Oil and Gas Sector
            Development Project for India was unsatisfactory. Although
            the two main objectives were achieved, the main condition of
            the project, to permit ONGC (Oil and Natural Gas Commission)
            to enter into joint ventures with international oil
            companies for the development of existing oil fields, was
            not met by the Government. The Ministry of Petroleum and
            Natural Gas has not yet acted on several proposals for joint
            ventures to develop existing fields. The project's
            sustainability is uncertain at this time, institutional
            development is negligible, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. The main lesson to be
            learned from this project is that the Government of India
            must continue to encourage foreign direct investment in its
            oil industry.

repnme.cdata!: India - Oil and Gas Sector Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Oil and Gas Sector Development Loan
            Project will complement the financing provided under the Gas
            Flaring Reduction Project (Ln 3364-IN). It will allow India
            to meet part of the external financing needs caused by the
            increase in oil imports resulting from the closure of oil
            wells with exceedingly high gas-oil ratios (GOR) in the
            Bombay High oilfield. The loan will: (i) support the
            Government's measures to attract private sector
            companies to participate in the accelerated development of
            India's oil and gas reserves; (ii) provide support to
            Oil and Natural Gas Commission (ONGC's) ongoing efforts
            to improve the management of the reservoirs of India's
            largest oilfield, the Bombay High.
